tr.td:
The patient was advised that the purpose of this urine drug screen is to monitor for compliance and to assist in risk stratification. The results of this preliminary screening test was discussed with the patient.
The urine sample is being sent for quantitative LCMS analysis of illicit drugs (Cocaine, Methamphetamine, Heroin, Fentanyl, THC, Synthetic Cannabinoids, Kratom, MDMA, PCP, and Synthetic Stimulants, Opiates (Codeine, Hydrocodone, Hydromorphone, and Morphine), Oxycodone, Oxymorphone, Methadone, Synthetic Opioids (Tramadol, Tapentadol, and Buprenorphine), Benzodiazepines (Alprazolam, Clonazepam, Lorazepam, Diazepam, Nordazepam, Oxazepam, and Temazepam), Gabapentin, Pregabalin, Muscle Relaxants (Carisoprodol, Cyclobenzaprine, and Meprobamate), Ketamine, Nalaxone, and Amphetamine, as this patient is being prescribed opioid medications for the first time at this practice. The purpose of this analysis is to confirm the patients stated medication usage and to establish baseline medication and metabolite quantities, and to evaluate for use of medications that are not prescribed or reported by the patient.
ORT and PHQ-9 testing was completed to evaluate the patient's psychosocial health to better determine baseline risk as we consider initiating opioid medications. The patient's ORT score of 1 indicates low risk potential for medication misuse. The patients PHQ-9 of 6 indicates mild depression.
Based on the above testing and my clinical judgement, I would consider the patient to be moderate risk.

Mrs. Gwyn presents today for initial evaluation. She has a chief complaint of low back pain. There is pain referring into the right gluteal region, right hip and then down the leg. She denies any focal numbness, tingling, or weakness. She has recently been worked up by an orthopedic doctor who ordered an MRI of her hip. I do not have these notes on this image to review. She has no recent imaging of the lumbar spine. I would like to order an MRI of the lumbar spine but she states she requires anesthesia before doing this. Were going to have to research on how to arrange this for this patient. The goal would be to get a better idea about what is going on in her back in order to be able to legitimately prescribed physical therapy, injections, and surgical consultation if necessary. Currently she is not a good candidate for narcotics. Her urine drug screen is testing positive for both marijuana and cocaine today. I am get a send this out for confirmatory testing. I am going to provide her with a TENS unit as she states this is helped her in the past.
• MRI, lumbar spine, w/o contrast - Please auth and schedule the patient and email appt information to longdustin@hotmail.com

albuterol sulfate 2.5 mg/3 mL (0.083 %) solution for nebulization
USE FOUR TIMES DAILY AS NEEDED FOR SHORTNESS OF AIR

amlodipine 10 mg tablet
TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH DAILY

atorvastatin 10 mg tablet
TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH DAILY FOR CHOLESTEROL

fluticasone propionate 50 mcg/actuation nasal spray,suspension
SHAKE LIQUID AND USE 1 SPRAY IN EACH NOSTRIL EVERY DAY

TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY 8 HOURS AS NEEDED

pantoprazole 40 mg tablet,delayed release
TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY DAY

TAKE 3 TABLETS BY MOUTH DAILY

prednisone 20 mg tablet
TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY DAY

sertraline 50 mg tablet
TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH DAILY CRUSHED WITH FOOD.
Spiriva with HandiHaler 18 mcg and inhalation capsules

tr.td:
2022-08-31
Long-term Drug Therapy; Degeneration of Lumbar Intervertebral Disc
Holly Bell, MD: 62490 Williams Extensions Apt. 234, Louisville, KY 41320, Ph. (+1-0003013577

Onset: date of onset:, 2 years, gradual onset. location:DjrSnNbcH paraspinal, radiating down the bilateral lower extremities to the calves. Context: started without cause. Quality: aching, gnawing, stabbing, throbbing, sharp, deep, constant, worsening. Functional Assessment-Severity: Pain Intensity Severe, current pain level: 8/10, average pain level: 8/10, worst pain level: 10/10. Alleviating Factors: heat. Aggravating Factors: sitting, standing, walking, ROM, weightbearing, exercise, upstairs, downstairs. Timing: constant. Associated Symptoms: no weakness, no swelling, no popping/clicking, no bowel incontinence, no urinary retention, no urinary incontinence, no perineal paresthesia/anesthesia, tingling, pain radiating down lower extremities. Prior Imaging: no recent studies. Previous Lumbar Surgery: none. Previous Injections: none. Previous physical therapy: dates:, response to therapy: no improvement in pain/symptoms, Facility:, PT discontinued by therapist/physician. Functional Assessment/Disability Index Living independently., Able to bathe/groom without assistance., Difficulty completing household chores secondary to pain., Difficulty exercising on a regular basis secondary to pain., Difficulty participating in recreation on a regular basis secondary to pain. Medications History: NSAIDs:, Muscle relaxants:, Neuropathics:, Opioid pain medications:. Prior Pain Management: no

Allergic/Immunologic
   Confirms: None
   Denies: Frequent Sneezing, Hives, Itching, Runny Nose, Sinus Pressure
Cardiovascular
   Confirms: None
   Denies: Arm Pain, Chest Pain, Known Heart Murmur, Lightheaded upon standing, Palpitations (skipping/irregular), Shortness of Breath (laying down), ShortnessofBreath (walking), Swollen Ankles / Legs
Constitutional
   Confirms: None
   Denies: Exercise Intolerance, Fatigue, Fever, Lethargy (Lack of Energy), Malaise, Sedation (Drowsiness), Weight Gain, Weight Loss
ENMT
   Confirms: Dry Mouth, Snoring
   Denies: Bleeding Gums, Difficulty Breathing, Ear Pain, Frequent Nosebleeds, Mouth Breathing, Mouth Ulcers, Oral Abnormalities, Sinus Problems, Sinusitis, Sore Throat
Endocrine
   Confirms: None
   Denies: Cold Intolerance, Fatigue, Hair Loss, Increased Hair Growth, Increased Thirst
Eyes
   Confirms: Wear Glasses
   Denies: Eye Disease or Injury, Irritation, Vision Change, Wear Contacts
Gastrointestinal
   Confirms: Abdominal Pain
   Denies: Appetite Change, Black or Tarry Stools, Constipation, Frequent Diarrhea, Heartburn, Indigestion, Nausea, Vomiting, Vomiting Blood
Genitourinary
   Confirms: None
   Denies: Blood in Urine, Frequent Urination, Incomplete Emptying, Trouble Urinating, Urinary Loss of Control
Hematologic/Lymphatic
   Confirms: None
   Denies: Anemia, Bruise Easily, Excessive Bleeding, Phlebitis (Vein Inflammation), Swollen Glands
Integumentary
   Confirms: Abnormal Moles, Dry Skin
   Denies: Breast Lumps, Change in Hair or Nails, Change in Skin Color, Growth Lesions, Itching, Jaundice, Lacerations, Non Healing Areas, Psoriasis, Rash
Musculoskeletal
   Confirms: Arthralgias/Joint Pain, Back Pain, Muscle Cramps / Aches, Muscle Weakness, Neck Pain
   Denies: Bone Pain, Difficulty Walking, Fractures, Osteoporosis (Fragile Bones), Swelling in Extremities
Neurologic
   Confirms: Restless Legs
   Denies: Dizziness, Frequent Headaches, Gait Dysfunction, Loss of Consciousness, Migraines, Numbness, Paralysis, Seizures, Tremors / Shaking, Weakness
Psychiatric
   Confirms: None
   Denies: Agitation, Alcohol Abuse, Delirium, Dementia, Depression, Feeling Unsafe in Relationship, Hallucinations, Memory Loss, Mood Swings, Restless Sleep, Sleep Disturbances, Suicidal Thoughts
Respiratory
   Confirms: Sleep Apnea
   Denies: Cough, Shortness of Breath, Wheezing
General Appearance: healthy-appearing, good personal hygiene. Level of Distress: no acute distress
Insight: good judgement and insight. Mental Status: active and alert, normal mood, normal affect
Motor Strength and Tone: normal, normal tone. Joints, Bones, and Muscles: limited ROM, tenderness
Gait: smooth, regular gait, ambulates without assistive device. Cranial Nerves II-XII: grossly intact. Sensation: abnormal. Sensation Right: decreased light touch L5 dermatome

Inspection: normal alignment. Bony Palpation of the Lumbar Spine: tenderness of the spinous process at L 5, tenderness of the lower, bilateral lumbar facet joints on the lower, bilateral, tenderness of the sacral promontory, tenderness of the sacrum. Bony Palpation of the Right Hip: tenderness of the iliac crest, tenderness of the PSIS, tenderness of the SI joint, tenderness of the greater trochanter. Active Range of Motion: flexion: 40 degrees, extension: 10 degrees, pain with motion. Left Straight Leg Raise: negative. Right Straight Leg Raise: negative

L1-2 Motor Strength on the Left: hip flexion (iliopsoas): 5/5. L1-2 Motor Strength on the Right: hip flexion (iliopsoas): 5/5. L2-L4 Motor Strength on the Left: knee extension(quadriceps): 5/5. L2-L4 Motor Strength on the Right: knee extension(quadriceps): 5/5. L5 Motor Strength on the Left: ankle dorsiflexion (tibialis anterior): 5/5, great toe extension (extensor hallucis longus): 5/5. L5 Motor Strength on the Right: ankle dorsiflexion (tibialis anterior): 5/5, great toe extension (extensor hallucis longus): 5/5. S1 Motor Strength on the Left: plantar flexion (gastrocnemius): 5/5. S1 Motor Strength on the Right: plantar flexion (gastrocnemius): 5/5
